Award.AwardTitle: Specifying the nature of the vocabulary gap

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States is facing an education crisis as far too many of our children enter school ill prepared to learn. Challenges to achievement begin early and are strongly connected to social disparities, with measures of vocabulary providing a particularly striking illustration. According to previous research, children from socioeconomically disadvantaged homes enter preschool knowing as many as 3000 fewer words than their peers. This gap persists into adolescence, with implications for later literacy and general academic success. This work moves beyond documenting these disparities to address how and why socioeconomic disparities lead to vocabulary differences. Specifically, the research investigates the hypothesis that differences in vocabulary may be the result of differences in children's basic ability to learn new words when the opportunity presents itself.

To this end, children from widely varying socioeconomic strata will be tested on several word learning tasks designed to index different component word learning skills. Their performance will be considered in relation to both measures of socioeconomic status and accumulated vocabulary. This project lays the foundation for an innovative approach to early intervention that focuses on teaching children how to learn words rather than solely on teaching words per se. This approach could powerfully facilitate the generalization of vocabulary gains well beyond the scope of words targeted in any particular intervention. In order for this approach to gain effective momentum, however, it is critical that this project first establish the role of word-learning skills in the 'vocabulary gap', and in so doing, identify which of a number of specific word-learning skills are in greatest need of educational intervention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is facing an education crisis as far too many of our children enter school ill prepared to learn. Challenges to achievement begin early and are strongly connected to social disparities, with measures of vocabulary providing a particularly striking illustration. On average, children from socioeconomically disadvantaged homes enter preschool knowing far fewer words than their peers. Unfortunately, this ‘vocabulary gap’ does not narrow appreciably over time. Moreover, persistent disparities in vocabulary have serious implications for literacy, and for broader academic achievement. Educators and scholars have designed various interventions aimed at closing this gap, but these have had limited success.

 

This project aimed to better understand the nature of socioeconomic disparities in early vocabulary by moving beyond consideration of the number of words known by children to an exploration of fundamental differences in children’s word-learning skills. To this end, 205 children from widely varying socioeconomic strata were tested on several word learning tasks (evaluating adherence to the mutual exclusivity assumption, the shape bias, the ability to capitalize on gaze and point following, and use of syntactic cues to meaning), and their performance was considered in relation to both measures of socioeconomic status and accumulated vocabulary.

 

As predicted, results revealed significant relationships between children’s early word learning skills and both their accumulated vocabulary (as measured by a standardized test) and their mother’s level of education (an indicator of socioeconomic status). Moreover, early word learning skill statistically mediated the previously established relationship between SES and vocabulary, suggesting that the origins of the vocabulary gap might be more complicated than previously thought. Of the word-learning skills under consideration, adherence to the mutual exclusivity assumption and the shape bias were most strongly related to both maternal education and vocabulary, suggesting that they might be particularly relevant to understanding the vocabulary gap. Analyses of relationships between early word learning skills and executive functioning and phonological processing abilities suggests that broader cognitive skills also must be considered in understanding this phenomenon.

 

These findings suggest that early-word learning skills might be a valuable target for early intervention efforts. Indeed, with this foundational information in hand, we can now confidently turn our attention to developing an innovative approach to narrowing vocabulary gaps that focuses on teaching children how to learn words rather than solely on teaching words per se. Importantly this approach could powerfully facilitate the generalization of vocabulary gains well beyond the scope of words targeted in any particular intervention.
